ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The class digs deep into democratic theory and looks at several real-world examples of democratic experiments.
Learned about democracy and its values, principles, reforms definitely made me think more critically about governments in general
An interesting blend of political theory and case studies of democratic innovations.

Philosophical argumentation; foundational knowledge on democratic theory and deliberative democracy as well as its strengths, weaknesses etc.; Wikipedia editing skills; insights on new possibilities for democracy.

This course was a huge paradigm shift for me in a way that the above words can't really encapsulate. It made me question so many assumptions I made about democracy and how we could redefine it for the future. This course renewed some optimism about the world for me.
I learned the theoretical and empirical arguments for several forms of democracy and practicede these arguments orally in class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Loved the presentation format and the group debates

A little more organization (e.g. using the Canvas assignments tab) would have been helpful, I often found myself unsure about due dates, assignment specifications, etc. 

I was very ambivalent about the Wikipedia assignments. Very unique but honestly didn't love it

Strengths: Very insightful and interesting readings; good facilitation of class discussions; a unique Wikipedia editing assignment; flexibility in assignments (converting the final essay to a group project if that's your thing, for example)

Weaknesses: Readings can be very lengthy sometimes and a few (minimal) readings are not provided; after the mid-term, the structure of the course becomes a bit difficult to understand, some clarification on that would be better to help students contextualise; general lack of non-eurocentric examples in the readings
It was innovative and interesting. At times the structure of assignments was unclear.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Prof Landemore is brilliant and at the cutting edge of this field-she is a great professor and class conversation moderator
This course carries my glowing recommendation.

Yes - absolutely 100%. This is an issue that strikes at the heart of our countries and democracies and a more critical understanding of the things we take for granted in politics is something that everyone should strive for. This course does precisely that and argues for a bold new shift in the way we think about politics. Whether or not you agree at the end of the day, the readings and assignments will at the very least get you to think deeply about deliberative democracy as an alternative on multiple scales, and hopefully provide at least some direction forward.

Professor Landemore is also very established in this field and is more than willing to provide further resources and readings if need be.
